photo.description: The Aztec Ruins National Monument preserves ancestral Pueblo structures in north-western New Mexico, United States, located close to the town of Aztec and northeast of Farmington, near the Animas River. Salmon Ruins and Heritage Park, with more ancestral Pueblo structures, lies a short distance to the south, just west of Bloomfield near the San Juan River. The buildings date back to the 11th to 13th centuries, and the misnomer attributing them to the Aztec civilization can be traced back to early American settlers in the mid-19th century. The actual construction was by the ancestral Puebloans, the Anasazi. The site was declared "Aztec Ruin National Monument" on January 24, 1923, and with a boundary change it was renamed "Ruins" on July 2, 1928. As an historical property of the National Park Service the National Monument was administratively listed on the National Register of Historic Places on October 15, 1966. Aztec Ruins was added to the UNESCO list of World Heritage Sites, as part of the Chaco Culture National Historical Park, on December 8, 1987. Anasazi settlements in North America started during the late 11th century and ran until around 1300. The Anasazi are believed to most likely have moved from these ruins into neighboring areas such as the present day Hopi and Navajo reserves and the pueblos of the Rio Grande Valley. These relocations occurred due to drought or loss of nearby fertile land. With no humans living within these, what are now ruins, their settlements slowly were covered by sand and were untouched until the mid-1800s. These ruins would not receive official protection until 1923 when the national monument was established. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aztec_Ruins_National_Monument en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Text_of_Creative_Commons_...

photo.description: This is one of the many ladders that line the walls of the Great Kiva. Signs are posted around the room, as well as outside, prohibiting the climbing on these ladders. Kivas are subterranean structures. At the top of each ladder is a covered room that sits at ground level. They share the same roof as the kiva itself. Each room at the top of the ladder is partitioned so that if one would want to go to another upper room, they would have to go outside the kiva and back in through another partitioned room, or go back down to the kiva and climb back up a different ladder.

photo.description: This may be a reconstruction, but it shows how the pillars inside the Great Kiva would have been constructed. Each layer has is comprised of a row of rock overlapped by a row of wrist-sized sticks topped by another layer of rocks. This layer of rock is topped by a row of sticks that runs perpendicular to the row of sticks below it. The process is repeated for as much as necessary.

photo.description: At the north end of the Great Kiva is a square anteroom that overlooks the round kiva. If this structure was made for communal meetings, top orators would probably have spoken from this point. Around the room is a continual bench. This style of architecture can be seen in Siberian and Chinese cultures, along with undoubted others. The pillars supporting the wooden ceiling were probably part of the original structure. This is seen by the intentional display of how the pillar is structured.

photo.description: These soapstone slabs were found buried in the Great Kiva. The purpose for these is unknown. However, underneath these slabs was a bag of turquoise powder and an animal fetish. These slabs remind me of a smaller version of the altars I've seen in Guatemala's Abaj Takalik. However, the Guatemalan altars predate the Aztec Ruins by roughly 900 years.

photo.description: This is the Great Kiva, placed prominently in the plaza area of the pueblo. The site was first found in 1859 by the Geologist, Dr. John S. Newberry. By 1916, under the management of the American Museum of Natural History, Earl H. Morris first excavated these ruins. In the 1930s, reconstruction of the Great Kiva, seen here, was undertaken. See the reconstruction as it looks today.

photo.description: The purpose of the round rooms seen in the pueblos, or kivas, is still unknown. Generally in archaeology when a function of an artifact or feature is unknown it will be attributed to ceremonial use. Such has been done with the kivas. Others think that these rooms may have had other purposes such as holding community meetings or was used as a communal storage unit for agricultural and other goods. Size may also have an impact on the structure's purpose. Smaller kivas may have been used for storage, while larger kivas may have been used for community gathering centers. One of the theories behind kivas being a communal room is that circular objects have a harder time being partitioned, especially when compared to blocked rooms that have corners and can be made into small blocked areas. This is area #3 on the model.

photo.description: These are the outer walls and rooms of the Aztec Ruins. These structures weren't actually built by the Aztecs but were rather named so by those who had heard the stories of Cortez from down south. The Aztecs were actually not in the picture until around AD 1200 and they were thought to have been mercenaries from the north. Still, this structure, and others in the area are not attributed to the Aztecs. This is area #2 on the model.

photo.description: Mesa Verde-style pottery post-dates the earlier Chaco pottery. As the description behind this piece describes, there are a few telling features that distinguish this type of pottery from others. The creation of this pottery involves the use of vegetable paint, solid designs, with a hard, white surface, they generally have ticked rims, and are square with thick walls.

photo.title: Mesa Verde-style Pottery

photo.description: Chaco-style pottery pre-dates the younger Mesa Verde-style pottery. As indicated by the description in the background, the Mesa Verde-style pottery consists of mineral paint, it generally has hatched designs with a chalky surface, the rims are often undecorated and tapered.

photo.title: Pot Rest

photo.description: The mano and metate which is the quintessential ground stone tool that is used all over Mesoamerica for grinding corn and other small seeds. These can also be used for grinding pigments for paint or other decorations.

photo.title: Mano & Metate

photo.description: This ground stone tool has a groove in it that seems to go around its circumference. This seems that it would be too large to be an adze although there might be some slight polishing on the left side. otherwise items like these could also be fishing weights. Again this seems unlikely with the size of the rivers running through the area. The display even seemed to be confused about the item as there was no further explanation, so I suppose it's fine that I can't figure this one out either. Any suggestions?

photo.title: Ground Stone Tool

photo.description: Tools of this size, maybe about the length of your hand (or somewhat smaller), are generally thought to be used as knives when knapped in this general shape. As the picture suggests these were often hafted to wooden, bone, or antler handles. The stone can also be inlaid into the handle like this knife that Craig Ratzat made.

photo.title: Stone Knives

photo.description: This is another example of a shoe found in the area. It seems like these would be more common, especially during the summer months. Again, these two are probably made from yucca. The bottom one looks like it was still in the process of being made and the ends sticking out would be cut when the shoe is finished.

photo.title: Woven Shoe

photo.description: A midden pile, or trash heap, can tell a lot about the culture living at the site in question. This is a piece of Mesa Verde-style ceramic which, when found in context can help tell who and when lived in an area at a given time. Not only can the ceramic itself be dated, but the charcoal seen in this replica could also be dated to give more support to the date of the pottery and the overall occupation time frame of the people in the area.
photo.tags: aztecruins newmexico aztec stratigraphy midden garbage layers levels profile wall archaeology bones ceramics pottery
photo.title: Ceramic in the Midden

photo.description: Kim didn't like that I used her as a scale for the size of this notched ladder. This was one of two types found in the area. This type seems like it would store easier and take up less space if you wanted to pull it up from where it was leaning. Most of the pueblos had two story rooms, so ladders were essential. Some rooms even had three stories. The description seen next to the ladder tells that it is around 900 years old. Dendrochronology is pretty amazing. I suppose radiocarbon dating could have worked in this instance as well.
photo.tags: aztecruins newmexico aztec ladder steps kim
photo.title: Notched Ladder

photo.description: These are some bone scrapers. These are probably deer humeri which have a nice rounded handle for scraping hides. The rounded end is probably put in the palm of the hand and the worked in is put on the hide being pushed away from the user. Hides do not preserve if you do not scrape them.
photo.tags: aztecruins newmexico aztec bone tool bonetool humerus humerii scraper hidescraper
photo.title: Bone Scrapers

photo.description: Kim seems very unwilling to pose as a scale for the rung ladder. This was one of two types of ladders found at the Aztec ruins. This ladder seems like it would be more stable and easier to use. For some reason when I think of Chaco Canyon and Mesa Verde, I think of defensive fortresses. These ladders seem like they would be better used in the inner walls rather than on the outer walls where the notched ladder might be more useful.
photo.tags: aztecruins newmexico aztec ladder rungs kim
photo.title: Rung Ladder

photo.description: Unfortunately with dim lighting and a bit of space between the glass and the item on display, it was hard to get good photos of many of the artifacts. Still, after being intrigued by pre- and protohistoric shoes from the Ainu exhibit, I thought I would include this woven shoe. Along with most of the woven organics, this shoe was probably made from yucca plant fibers. This is just a guess, but this one might be more useful in the winter where you can stuff fibrous material in the shoe with your foot as insulation. During the summer months a sandal may have been the preferred shoe.
photo.tags: aztecruins newmexico aztec woven shoe weave yucca weaving
photo.title: Woven Shoe

photo.description: This is an example of yucca cloth, a bit tattered, but still a good example. I don't know how the red was made, whether by cochineal like the Aztecs and Mayan used, or by some other method.
photo.tags: aztecruins newmexico aztec weave basket yucca red cloth
photo.title: Weaving

photo.description: This basket was made from willow and coiled into the form seen here. The basket could actually hold water when its user lined the inside with a pith that gave it a watertight seal. The item in the foreground is called a burden strap. People would put the wider area around the forehead and attach a load such as firewood that rested on the person's back. This would allow the carrier to efficiently transport more weight than would be generally be possible if carried by the armload.
photo.tags: aztecruins newmexico aztec weave basket burdenstrap willow coiled waterproof pitch
photo.title: Coiled Basket & Burden Strap

photo.description: This collection of pottery was held at the beginning of the back room display where all of the photographed artifacts in this set were held. This case had no explanation and I took this mostly for the blowfish-looking vessel on the right. If I had to choose that these were either the Chaco or the Mesa Verde-style pottery as given by their brief descriptions, I'd have to go with Mesa Verde at least for the piece on the left because it has a decorated rim and has solid designs. The container in the back may be Chacoan based on its hatched design. The piece on the right I am not willing to take a guess with. It should also be noted, however, that there are a lot of different pottery styles in the area beyond just the Chaco and Mesa Verde with probable overlap between them all so classifying may be harder than it seems. I'll leave the ceramic typologies to the professionals.

photo.title: Aztec Ruins Pottery
